Blogo¶

class blogo.Blogo(name='Blogo')¶

A class which describes a turtle and has functions to move it in space.

add_cap(is_start_cap, cs_name='')¶

Put in a cap in the shape of the current cross section, facing forwards or backwards

Parameters

is_start_cap – If True then the cap will face backwards, otherwise forwards

add_end_cap(cs_name='')¶

Put in a cap in the shape of the current cross section, facing forwards

add_follower(turtle)¶

Add a follower turtle to this turtle.

Each action which causes a turn or a forward to the current turtle will also be made to the follower turtle

Parameters

turtle (Blogo) – The turtle who should follow the current turtle.

add_gap(name, start_height, end_height, widths1=('above', 'left', 'right'), widths2=('below', 'left', 'right'), gap_cs_shape='square', cs_splitting='')¶

Add a window in the middle of a cross section

The gap is made by squashing the original cross section to the bottom and adding in a new cross section above.

Parameters

  • name – The name of the new cross section area

  • start_height – The height of the bottom of the gap

  • end_height – The height of the top of the gap

  • widths1 – The edges of the original cross section to copy into the new cross section (default (‘above’, ‘left’, ‘right’) - i.e. the new cross section goes at the top, with the same width)

  • widths2 – The edges of the original cross section to leave in the original cross section (default (‘below’, ‘left’, ‘right’) - i.e. the original cross section goes at the bottom, with the same width)

  • gap_cs_shape – Cross section shape to make the additional cross section (Default: ‘square’)

  • cs_splitting – The name of the cross section to split. (Default “”, i.e. the main cross section)

add_start_cap(cs_name='')¶

Put in a cap in the shape of the current cross section, facing backwards

add_width_func(name, func=None, cs_name='', **kwargs)¶

Add either a width function to a side

Parameters

  • name – The side of the cross section to deal with. This can be a single side, (‘left’, ‘right’, ‘above’, ‘below’) or it can be a list of those sides or it can be a description of multiple sides (‘sides’, ‘verticals’, ‘all’)

  • func – The function to add, or None to remove all functions

  • kwargs – User data to pass on to the function when called

anticlockwise(angle)¶

Rotate anti-clockwise by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to rotate anti-clockwise by

arc(angle, radius, steps=None)¶

Move the turtle in an arc

The turtle will move in an arc round for angle degrees, with a given radius. If steps is specified the arc will be made up of that made straight sections.

Parameters

  • angle – The interior angle of the arc in degrees. If this is positive the arc moves round to the right, otherwise to the left.

  • radius – The distance from the centre of the arc

  • steps – The number of straight lines to construct the arc from (default = angle)

backward(dist)¶

Move the turtle backward by dist

Move the turtle backwards (or forwards if negative) by dist. If the pen is down it will trail behind it defined by the current cross section and width modifiers.

Parameters

dist (int, float) – Distance to move

bk(dist)¶

Move the turtle backward by dist

Move the turtle backwards (or forwards if negative) by dist. If the pen is down it will trail behind it defined by the current cross section and width modifiers.

Parameters

dist (int, float) – Distance to move

circle(radius, direction='right', steps=None)¶

Draw a circle with a given radius

Parameters

  • radius – The radius of the circle.

  • direction – The side the circle should be draw on, “right” (default) or “left”

  • steps – The number of straight lines to draw the circle from. Default: 360

clean_up()¶

Draw all outstanding Blogo instances

clockwise(angle)¶

Rotate clockwise by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to rotate clockwise by

copy(deep_copy=False, new_location=(0, 0, 0), relative_location=True)¶

Returns a copy of the current Blogo instance

Parameters

  • deep_copy (bool) – If True then the existing Blender objects will be duplicated, if False the copy is still fairly deep, but no new objects

  • new_location (tuple) – The new location of the copy, either absolute or relative

  • relative_location (bool) – Indicates if new_location should be absolute or moved relative to the current turtle position

Return type

Blogo

copy_pos(turtle)¶

Move the turtle and the orientation to the same as another turtle.

Parameters

turtle (TurtlePosition) – The turtle to copy

curve_to(end_position, end_direction, start_strength=1.0, end_strength=1.0)¶

Draw a cubic Bézier curve between the current position and then end position.

Parameters

  • end_position (tuple) – The final position of the curve

  • end_direction (tuple) – A vector for the tangent at the end of the curve

  • start_strength (int, float) – The proportion of the curve which should be influenced by the start direction.

  • end_strength (int, float) – The proportion of the curve which should be influenced by the end direction.

dn(angle)¶

Rotate downwards by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to rotate downwards by

down(angle)¶

Rotate downwards by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to rotate downwards by

ellipse(radius1, radius2, angle=360, steps=None)¶

Draw an ellipse starting at radius1 from the centre of the ellipse, curving to the extreme radius2 from the centre on the other axis and then looping round

Parameters

  • radius1 – Distance from centre of ellipse to starting point

  • radius2 – Distance from centre of ellipse to the point on the ellipse at 90°

  • angle – Number of degrees to go round ellipse (default: complete ellipse)

  • steps – Number of straight lines to draw the ellipse from (default = angle)

fd(dist)¶

Move the turtle forward by dist

Move the turtle forward (or backwards if negative) by dist. If the pen is down it will trail behind it defined by the current cross section and width modifiers.

Parameters

dist (int, float) – Distance to move

fill(from_value, to_value, texture, fill_type='relative')¶

Fill the current shape when either finished or the pen is put up.

The gap between the centre of the cross section and the limits from from_value to to_value is filled with the given texture. If fill_type is ‘relative’ then the limits with be a floating point value (generally between 0 and 1) where 0 is the lowest point on the cross section and 1 is the highest point. If the fill_type is ‘relative-reversed’ then it is the same as ‘relative’, but measured down from the top. If fill_type is ‘absolute’ then to_value and from_value refer to actual measurements from the base of the cross section. If fill_type is ‘absolute-reversed’ then to_value and from_value refer to actual measurements from the top of the cross section.

Parameters

  • from_value – The bottom vertical position to fill from

  • to_value – The top vertical position to fill to

  • texture – The texture to fill with

  • fill_type – One of ‘relative’, ‘relative-reversed’, ‘absolute’, ‘absolute-reversed’

Returns

A mesh object, which can be passed to fill_stop to stop filling.

fill_stop(fill_mesh=None)¶

Remove either all or one single fill from the current turtle.

Parameters

fillMesh – The mesh (returned by fill to remove, or if None then all fills will be removed (default None)

forward(dist)¶

Move the turtle forward by dist

Move the turtle forward (or backwards if negative) by dist. If the pen is down it will trail behind it defined by the current cross section and width modifiers.

Parameters

dist (int, float) – Distance to move

get_path_position(pos, units='relative')¶

Get the position that the turtle was in a certain way along the current path.

This can be used to place other objects along the route that this turtle has taken.

Parameters

  • pos – A distance along the current path

  • units – Either ‘relative’ for pos to be interpretted as the whole path between 0 and 1, or ‘absolute’ to give a distance along the path.

Returns

A position and orientation of a turtle

  • cs_name – The name of the cross section affected (default=””)

Return the turtle to the origin

join_objects(union=False)¶

Join the underlying blender objects of this turtle into one object

Parameters

union – If True the joined objects will be merged into one block with a binary operation, otherwise they will be separatable by using unjoin.

parse(text, var=None, var_name='var')¶

This will parse a block of text and then execute it.

Any function used which is a member function in Blogo will be modified to run in the context of this turtle. Any brackets missing around member functions arguments will be added. Thus:

turtle.parse("fd 10; rt 90; fd 10; rt 90")

will be executed as:

turtle.fd(10)
turtle.rt(90)
turtle.fd(10)
turtle.rt(90)

The argument var can be a dictionary used to pass in variables and have the code block read and modify them, with var_name specifying what name the dictionary is refered to by in the code block. e.g.:

data["size"] = 10
turtle.parse('fd data["size"];rt 90;fd data["size"]', data, "data")

Will move forward 10, turn right, then move forward 10 again.

Any valid python can be passed in to the code block, but could get fragile if too much code is passed in.

Parameters

  • text – Block of code to parse

  • var – Dictionary to be able to get and set variables in code block

  • var_name – Name of the variable used to hold the dictionary in the code block

parse_file(file, var=None, var_name='var')¶

Open a file and call parse with the contents of the file

Parameters

  • file – Name of file containing a block of code to parse

  • var – Dictionary to be able to get and set variables in code block

  • var_name – Name of the variable used to hold the dictionary in the code block

pd()¶

Put the pen down.

Putting the pen down means that a trail will be left behind the turtle in the shape of the current cross section.

pen_down()¶

Put the pen down.

Putting the pen down means that a trail will be left behind the turtle in the shape of the current cross section.

pen_up()¶

Put the pen up.

Putting the pen up means that a trail will not be left behind the turtle.

polygon(sides, lengths, angles=None)¶

Draw a polygon with a given number of sides.

Draws a polygon. If the number of lengths or angles given is equal to the number of sides, then the polygon may not be closed

Parameters

  • sides – The number of sides the polygon should have

  • lengths – Either an int/float giving the length of every side, or a list of the lengths of each side

  • angles – If given then either an int/float giving every angle, or a list of the angles after each side.

pu()¶

Put the pen up.

Putting the pen up means that a trail will not be left behind the turtle.

rectangle(length1, length2)¶

Draws a rectangle

Parameters

  • length1 – The length of the first and third sides

  • length2 – The length of the second and fourth sides

remove_follower(turtle)¶

Remove a follower turtle that has been added with add_follower

Parameters

turtle (Blogo) – The turtle who should not follow the current turtle.

remove_gap(name)¶

Remove a gap that has been previously added by`add_gap`

Parameters

name – The name of the gap to remove

remove_width_func(name, func, remove_all=True)¶

Remove either a specific width function from a side, or remove all width functions from that side.

Parameters

  • name – The side of the cross section to deal with. This can be a single side, (‘left’, ‘right’, ‘above’, ‘below’) or it can be a list of those sides or it can be a description of multiple sides (‘sides’, ‘verticals’, ‘all’)

  • func – The function to remove, or None to remove all functions

  • remove_all – If True then if a function has been added more than once then all will be removed, otherwise only the first occurance will be. (default: True)

replay(turtle, from_label='start', to_label='end', allowed_command_types='all')¶

Replay a number of commands from this turtle in another turtle’s context

Parameters

  • turtle –

  • from_label –

  • to_label –

  • allowed_command_types –

reset(init=False)¶

Return the turtle to the origin and remove all modifiers

reset_cross_section()¶

Reset the cross section to a square

reset_length_counter(name, include_bk=- 1, include_pu=False, value=0.0)¶

Reset a value used by a length counter

Sets the given length counter to value, specifies how backward movements should be treated, and whether the counter should be increased when the pen is up.

Parameters

  • name (string) – The name of the length counter to reset

  • include_bk (int) – 0 to ignore backwards movements, 1 to include backwards movements, -1 to subtract backwards movements

  • include_pu (bool) – True to increase the counter when the pen is up, False to leave the counter when the pen is up

  • value (int, float) – The value to reset the counter to.

reset_multipliers(cs_name=None)¶

Reset width multipliers to 1

right(angle)¶

Turn right by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to turn right by

rt(angle)¶

Turn right by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to turn right by

set_alpha(alpha)¶

Set the alpha (transparency) value for the current texture.

If a texture is a rgba colour tuple, then this value will be multiplied by the tuple alpha value.

Parameters

alpha – A value between 0 (completely transparent) and 1 (completely opaque) to set the texture alpha to

set_cross_section(shape, multiplier_h=1.0, multiplier_v=None, name='')¶

Set the cross section shape of the current turtle.

The shape can either be a list of two dimensional points or one of ‘square’ or ‘circleN’, where N is an integer specifying how many points the circle should be made up of (just ‘circle’ will use a value of N=100).

A ‘square’ cross section will create a unit square from (-0.5, -0.5) to (0.5, 0.5)

Parameters

  • shape – Either a list of points or ‘square’, ‘circle’, ‘circle10’, ‘circle500’, etc

  • multiplier_h – A multiplier to multiply the left and right by (default: 1.0)

  • multiplier_v – A multiplier to multiply the top and bottom by. If None it will use the same value as multiplier_h (default: None)

  • name – The name of the cross section to change

set_fill_smart_project(smart_project)¶

Sets whether the fill texture should be smart projected.

Some textured Blogo shapes look better with smart project on, but it will take longer to create the objects.

Parameters

smart_project – True or False depending on whether to smart project the fill texture or not.

set_fill_texture_scale(texture_scale)¶

Set the texture scale of the current fill.

When using a image as a fill texture this will scale the image. A value of 0 will give an attempt to scale the image proportionally to the size of the object. Any other number will scale the image by that amount. A value of None will leave the scale as Blender’s default.

Parameters

texture_scale – The scale factor to use, or 0 for auto.

set_fill_unwrap(unwrap)¶

Sets whether the mesh should be unwrapped before applying the texture to the current fill.

Some textured Blogo shapes look better with unwrapping on, but it will take longer to create the objects.

Parameters

unwrap – True or False depending on whether to unwrap the object before applying the fill texture or not.

set_global_origin(origin_y=0, origin_z=0)¶

Change the origin used by all instances of Blogo.

Parameters

  • origin (tuple, int, float) – Either a tuple containing the origin’s location or the x location

  • origin_y (int, float) – y coordinate of the origin (defaults to either 0 or value given in origin if tuple)

  • origin_z (int, float) – z coordinate of the origin (defaults to either 0 or value given in origin if tuple)

set_heading(angle)¶

Set the heading angle of the turtle, from 0 to 360 degrees.

Parameters

angle – The new heading, 0 - 360 or ‘north’, ‘east’, ‘south’, ‘west’

set_heading_towards(coord)¶

Set the heading to be towards the given coordinate

Parameters

coord – A tuple giving a position

set_heading_vec(vec)¶

Set the heading to be the same as the given vector

Parameters

vec – A tuple giving a vector

set_height(name, value=1.0, cs_name='')¶

Set one or more of the width modifiers to a named value.

If only a number parameter is supplied then it will set both above and below to that multiplier.

Parameters

  • name – The name or names of the sides to set, or a value to set above and below to if a number

  • value – The value to set the modifier to. The cross section distance from the middle is multiplied by this value

  • cs_name – The name of the cross section affected (default=””)

set_length_incr(incr, incr_mul=None)¶

Set how often any width functions should be called when moving forwards or backwards.

The incr value gives a maximum distance to move before recalculating the width. The incr_mul value gives the maximum proportion of the line to move before recalculating. For example, incr=0.1 and incr_mul=0.01 will mean that to draw a line 8 long, incr says width must be recalculated every 0.1, but incr_mul says it must be done every 0.08, therefore the forward will be done in steps of 0.08. To draw a line 80 long, incr says it must be done in steps of 0.1, but incr_mul says the steps should be no longer than 0.8 - therefore the forward will be done in steps of 0.1

If either incr or incr_mul are None then their values will not be changed.

Parameters

  • incr – An absolute maximum length of step before recalulating the width of the line.

  • incr_mul – A maximum length of step before recalulating the width of the line, relative to the length of the line

set_origin(origin=0, origin_y=0, origin_z=0)¶

Change the origin used by this turtle.

Parameters

  • origin (tuple, int, float) – Either a tuple containing the origin’s location or the x location

  • origin_y (int, float) – y coordinate of the origin (defaults to either 0 or value given in origin if tuple)

  • origin_z (int, float) – z coordinate of the origin (defaults to either 0 or value given in origin if tuple)

set_pos(position, move_type='absolutely-relative')¶

Set the position of the turtle.

If any values in the position tuple are left out or set to None then the current position in that axis will be kept.

Parameters

  • position (tuple) – A tuple of the position to move to

  • move_type – One of ‘absolute’ (move to that location), ‘relative’ (move by that much) or ‘absolutely-relative’ (move to that position, but any followers should move by the relative equivalent)

set_smart_project(smart_project)¶

Sets whether the texture should be smart projected.

Some textured Blogo shapes look better with smart project on, but it will take longer to create the objects.

Parameters

smart_project – True or False depending on whether to smart project the texture or not.

set_texture(texture)¶

Set a new texture for the cross section to be drawn covered in.

The texture can be a tuple of rgb colours (each in range 0 -> 1), or a named colour or an image filename.

Parameters

texture – The texture to use.

set_texture_scale(texture_scale)¶

Set the texture scale.

When using a image as a texture this will scale the image. A value of 0 will give an attempt to scale the image proportionally to the size of the object. Any other number will scale the image by that amount. A value of None will leave the scale as Blender’s default.

Parameters

texture_scale – The scale factor to use, or 0 for auto.

set_turtle(turtle)¶

Set the turtle position to a copy of turtle

Parameters

turtle (TurtlePosition) – The turtle to copy

set_unwrap(unwrap)¶

Sets whether the mesh should be unwrapped before applying the texture.

Some textured Blogo shapes look better with unwrapping on, but it will take longer to create the objects.

Parameters

unwrap – True or False depending on whether to unwrap the object before applying the texture or not.

Set the heading of the turtle, from 0 to 360 degrees.

Parameters

angle – The new vertical heading, 0 - 360 or ‘up’, ‘backward’, ‘down’, ‘forward’

set_v_heading_towards(coord)¶

Set the heading to be towards the given coordinate

Parameters

coord – A tuple giving a position

set_v_heading_vec(vec)¶

Set the heading to be the same as the given vector

Parameters

vec – A tuple giving a vector

set_width(name, value=1.0, cs_name='')¶

Set one or more of the width modifiers to a named value.

If only a number parameter is supplied then it will set both left and right to that multiplier.

Parameters

  • name – The name or names of the sides to set, or a value to set left and right to if a number

  • value – The value to set the modifier to. The cross section distance from the middle is multiplied by this value

  • cs_name – The name of the cross section affected (default=””)

  • y – The position to set the turtle on the y axis

  • z – The position to set the turtle on the z axis

  • z – The position to set the turtle on the z axis

dist (int, float) – Distance to move

strafe_v(dist)¶

Move the turtle upwards by dist

Move the turtle upwards (or down if negative) by dist. If the pen is down it will trail behind it defined by the current cross section and width modifiers.

Parameters

dist (int, float) – Distance to move

tilt_h(angle)¶

Parameters

Parameters

tilt_v(angle)¶

Tilt the cross section in the vertical axis by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to tilt vertically by

triangle(length, angles=None)¶

Draw a three sided polygon.

Parameters

  • length – Either an int/float giving the length for an equilateral triangle, or a list giving the length of the sides.

  • angles – If not given then a closed triangle will be drawn from the given lengths, otherwise an int/float or list of angles (triangle may not be closed)

up(angle)¶

Rotate upwards by angle degrees

Parameters

angle – Number of degrees to rotate upwards by
